title: Permeance
text:
Permeance, in general, is the degree to which a material admits a flow of <a href="matter">matter</a> or <a href="energy">energy</a>. Permeance is usually represented by a curly capital P: formula_1. 
Electromagnetism.
In <a href="electromagnetism">electromagnetism</a>, permeance is the inverse of <a href="reluctance">reluctance</a>. In a magnetic circuit, permeance is a measure of the quantity of <a href="magnetic%20flux">magnetic flux</a> for a number of current-turns. A <a href="magnetic%20circuit">magnetic circuit</a> almost acts as though the <a href="flux">flux</a> is conducted, therefore permeance is larger for large cross-sections of a material and smaller for smaller cross section lengths. This concept is analogous to <a href="electrical%20conductance">electrical conductance</a> in the <a href="electric%20circuit">electric circuit</a>.
Magnetic permeance formula_1 is defined as the reciprocal of <a href="magnetic%20reluctance">magnetic reluctance</a> formula_3 (in analogy with the reciprocity between electric conductance and resistance):
which can also be re-written:
using (magnetic circuit analogue of <a href="Ohm%27s%20law">Ohm's law</a> for electric circuits) and the definition of <a href="magnetomotive%20force">magnetomotive force</a> (magnetic analogue of <a href="electromotive%20force">electromotive force</a>):

Alternatively in terms of <a href="permeability%20%28electromagnetism%29">magnetic permeability</a> (analogous to <a href="electric%20conductivity">electric conductivity</a>):
where:
The SI unit of magnetic permeance is the <a href="henry%20%28unit%29">henry</a> (H), that is "webers per ampere-turn".
Materials science.
In <a href="materials%20science">materials science</a>, permeance is the degree to which a material transmits another substance.
